course.description: Structured knowledge representation; knowledge-based methods of reasoning and learning; problem-solving, modeling and design.

reviews.body:
NOTE: DO NOT TAKE THIS CLASS!

I haven’t reviewed any of my other classes, but I’m making an exception for this one because I disliked it so much that I feel compelled to warn others. I expected this course to be an enjoyable, easy experience, like CS-6795 (Intro to Cognitive Science), but instead, it focuses on basic concepts and how AI agents mimic human behavior. Unfortunately, you'll spend your time on pointless tasks: 5 mini-projects, 3 homework assignments, 4 milestones for a major project, and 2 exams. Every week, you're also required to peer review three classmates' papers, but most people barely skim them for participation points. The projects are tedious and offer no real learning value—you won’t be working on anything cutting-edge or relevant to your future career. For each assignment, you’ll end up writing around 5 pages, totaling 65-70 pages for the entire course. If you're serious about learning something that will advance your career, do not take this class. I wish I had read the reviews before enrolling.

TLDR: Do NOT take this course - you will spend an incredible amount of time but learn next to nothing out of it.

This has been an absolutely worst class for me, not only in the program but probably among the other 20+ graduate courses I've taken throughout my life. There was maybe a course or two where I learned less but then they required much less work. There were courses with higher workload, but then I learned much more from them. This course feels like an incredible amount of busy but absolutely useless work. Even the lectures: very lengthy but with minimal breadth. A student in our class summarized the content of the entire course in a 19 page PDF and that was all in it. And even this summarized material has very little to no practical use.
Some mini-projects and the course-long project were kind of fun to work on but they had nothing to do with the course material. 
Also, keep in mind that each programming assignment should be accompanied with a write-up. On top of that, there are 3 homeworks that are purely write-ups.  So it feels that you are taking an English class, not a CS one. To complete the picture, the questions on the exams were also worded in an incomprehensible way.
The only good thing in this course for me was that working on the course-long project I got an intro to OpenCV that I wanted to learn.
Finally, if you care about your grade (that I was not much though somehow managed to get an A), the written parts are graded absolutely arbitrarily and no re-grade request were acknowledged.

My Background: B.S. in CS from a reputable university. 4 YOE as a SWE. I've taken CS 7646 and 6310. I found CS 7646 was good preparation for this course, but consider CS 7646 more difficult than this one in many ways.

Course Performance: Safe 'A'.

Recommended Background: Have Python experience before taking this course as its first projects require OOP Python from the get go with no build up. Know your graph algorithms - especially breadth-first search. There are courses on edX by Georgia Tech that can provide the required Python background for this course if you don't have prior experience.

Tips to Do Well in the Course: 
1.) To get full participation points when reviewing classmates' papers, use the grading rubric for the assignment to structure your response.
2.) Write your project journals based off of the grading rubric for time efficiency and to ensure you cover all required items.
3.) Scoring well on the final project's performance section will take way more effort than other assignments. Accept that your grade is going to take a hit on the final project and ensure you do well on all assignments before the final project.
4.) For mini-projects you don't necessarily need to worry too much about efficiency. Try a simple, brute force approach first then seek to optimize your solution.
5.) Take page-numbered notes during the lectures and organize them by a table of contents. Reference those notes and ctrl-f search the transcripts of the video lessons for exams for any questions you're unsure on. The timing of the exams was nice and not intensely pressured like many OMSCS courses.
6.) Do Peer Feedback tasks and do them early. You get 3 times as many points for doing them early. Try to do as many as possible in the beginning of the course to frontload the workload for the course as much as you can.
7.) Prioritize doing extra peer feedback tasks for the RPM project so you can learn from your classmate's approaches. Keep a google doc of notes of things you learn from your classmates that you may want to incorporate.
8.) Participate in the EdDiscussions in ways that are enjoyable for you. For me that was answering classmates' questions and participating in the Wednesday Debates.
9.) Pay attention to JDF format! Ensure your margins and font size are correct. They mostly care grade-wise if you're using margins or font sizes that allow you to write more than other students. Create a Google Doc template that follows JDF format and make a copy of this before each assignment to efficiently ensure you follow the required report format.
10.) Monitor EdDiscussions. The course is set up to be very collaborative. Learn from your classmates and their posts.

Course Thoughts:

The course material is very interesting. Knowledge-based AI is more intuitive in that you can understand how an agent arrives at its answers. This course provides interesting methodologies to allow your agents (programs) to learn that differ from machine learning. The course feels like it supplements an algorithms course in that it explores problem-solving strategies and gives a more intuitive language to algorithms than I had encountered before.

The course is well-organized and the expectations are clear. The course has a demanding workload, but I would not say it's overly difficult as some of the posts here state. Start your assignments early and do not procrastinate. All course material and assignments are available from day one.

Course Critique:

1.) The homework assignments are busy work. Their material is already covered by the mini-projects. I think the level of work for the course is appropriate except for these homework assignments.
2.) The course project revolving around Raven's Progressive Matrices (RPM) is really interesting! Unfortunately, the need to learn vision processing to apply the course concepts encourages much easier, gimmicky strategies that do much better. I think this course could be greatly improved if the vision processing necessary to create conceptual models and analogical mappings of the RPM problems was taught as part of the course. This would help students that want to take that approach to apply the concepts from the course more. Otherwise, the concepts from the course get rather disconnected from the final project through the use of DPR, IPR, and case recording which score extremely well but don't really apply course concepts. Meanwhile, actual vision processing based strategies applying the course concepts require way more work and don't perform as well.

The semester long project was very rewarding and fun to work on - but it was worth very little of your total grade. 7.5% for the report, 7.5% for the actual code. Getting 90-100 percent on coding assignments didn't take much effort (and were fun!), but the written reports accompanying the homework assignments are graded according to a rubric that is ---not--- 1:1 to the assignment instructions. 

Make sure to read the report rubrics and title sections/bold phrases exactly as they appear in the rubric. <---------

If you do the first few assignments without realizing this, you will lose a good percent of your grade. Especially in Summer - you will be turning in multiple assignments before you get your first batch of grades. Given written reports (outside the final report) are 47.5% of your grade, getting 2-3 bad grades without realizing this can significantly impact your grade and make it unnecessarily difficult. 

You don't really need any pre-reqs for this course - know some basic Python and you're okay - this is a good intro course. 

tl;dr
I recommend the course and found the content fun and rewarding, but be aware that the project and tests are not the most important grade-wise.

The lectures are enjoyable and thought provoking, but not very informative and very abstract. it doesnt map to algorithms most of the time. The negatives here are as follows, the course provides no exxtra value than watching the  videos on youtube or without actually enrolling to the course. There are no office hours , tutorials nor TA engagment like other courses, grading is alway super late, and feedback is a few words so not helpful to learn from TA correction. Also course load is way more than the learning value as you have to write and review alot, which doesnt help the learning process as much as they portray it. This course relies on the fact that class participation is graded so that people help each other rather than TAs supportting which in my view didnt work much. Its easy to get an A if you put the effort although effort does weight well aganist the amount of learning. Last nitpick is you re betteroff implementing most projects from you prior algorithm knowledge than trying to implement philosphies in lecture and after just attempt to link them together which is also disappointing somewhat since course knowledge is not needed for any of the project even the final ravens project. for final project go for simple pixel and image difference approaches saves you so much effort and time from trying to apply course shape relationships and will get you a higher grade.

Horrible class....the concepts are good but the staff is absolutely abysmal. Students are setup for failure. It is quite evident in almost every GT OMSCS class. You can literally see students crying and complaining but the staff takes no interest and just says "Yeah well thats the standard of GT". They are right... bad teaching is a standard at GT. Students are setup for failure here....Dont do OMSCS. Go to a school that cares about your mental health.  So many better schools like UT Austin, Purdue etc. where they actually care about what matters and not stupid stuff.

Review #2 Summer 2024
learned nothing, forced to see psychotherapist 3 times, chiropractors 5 times. Dropped

One question: Why do I want to read the garbage other people has written using chatgpt 3x or 6x every week?

Took it as my first course while working full time. I do have a decent amount of experience in software but not with Python, which is the language we used for all of our projects in this class. wrapping up with python and getting familiar with some of the libraries look some time but was not the main problem. This course has ALOT of weekly tasks which makes it a very difficult first class. On top of trying to get back into school, especially an online school, and learning how to use Python to deliver the projects which one is due almost every week, we had to write 5 page papers weekly, do at least 3 peer reviews, watch 2-3 lessons that were sort of boring, midterm, final, and a very difficult final project which we gradually build during the whole class timeline that hold a pretty big chunk of the overall grade .I had a 90% and it dropped to 86% because the TA gave me a super low grade on the paper, although I had been receiving mostly A's on all my papers. 

Its a good class, but I wouldn't suggest it as the first class due to overload of assignments due per week.
Feels like another crappy course so far

This was my first course in OMSCS, I thought it was a solid introduction and ramped me up well. I had a solid professional background in software going in (undergrad in CS, SWE full-time) and found the coding assignments provided reasonable value and were very approachable.

The most valuable part of the course was the context of AI, the introduction to and histories of the topic, and the approach of development for various solutions. The term-long project can be daunting at first, but was a fun challenge by the end of the term - it's very approachable if you build cleanly from the start and meet the milestones as recommended.

There was a fair amount of writing, probably 50-60 total pages of reporting in JDF throughout the course. This was my first time using the format and it's quite approachable. The rubrics for these assignments were very refined and it was easy to get full marks by referring to the rubric and assignment description - they explicitly state what they're looking for.

Lastly, the staff were extremely helpful and very organized. In contrast to some other courses, they're on another level in terms of successful course management.

WHAT A WASTE OF TIME! This was my 7th course in the program and by far was my least favorite. I did not learn anything at all. The lectures are so boring. All my time wasted for tedious reports and peer reviews. There are a couple of interesting mini-projects at the beginning but the rest are so useless. Homeworks are the worst part of the deliverables.
Tip:
For peer reviews, write a lot and do not just write the three required ones. Go for extra peer reviews if you want to get a good participation point. I lost some points since allegedly my reviews were not detailed enough.

This is the BEST OMSCS course I've taken so far. This to know: 

- There is a ton of writing and peer reviews. Very similar to HCI. 
- There is a semester-long project to build an AI Agent. You can find tons of information about this all over the internet. 
- An 'A' is possible with 10-15 hours of work each week.
- There are mini-projects throughout the course that can be brute forced. Don't overthink them. You're trying to get an A, not impress a leetcode interviewer.

This was my first course in OMSCS. 

Honestly a really well-structured course, it becomes very apparent that they have been considerate of different learning styles and different viewpoints. Lectures are impressively well-put together. Instructor and TAs were really accessible and responsive. Content was pretty easy to digest, and complexity of assignments were very fair (sometimes too easy).

However...terribly time consuming. Almost weekly, we had to do some coding assignment, write a paper about it, and do some peer reviews on top of that. While it's still quite an easy course, sometimes it feels like there's very little time for a break, so work ahead whenever possible!

My background: I am a software engineer with a few years experience, and I have a BS in Computer Science. 

In general, this class was fairly interesting, but nothing too exciting or challenging. The main course project revolves around solving problems in "Ravens Progressive Matrices" (those IQ test type questions with 3 images, and you have to solve for the fourth one). This project was fun to screw around with, but it was not really related to any of the lectures. I was able to get ~70/96 by just screwing around with my own heuristics and not reading any papers that others were using to score higher.

The lectures themselves were pretty interesting and well organized. I wish I spent more time just listening to them for fun, but as I said it was hard to apply most of them to the main RPM project. There were six mini coding projects that related to the course materials that were pretty interesting and not too hard. There were some written homeworks as well which were more annoying than anything, but they were fine. 

There was a lot of drama related to participation, but in my opinion it was extremely easy to get a high participation grade by just doing the reviews at the beginning of the week, requesting extra in the beginning, and posting on the forum for extra points. I got way more than the max points without even really thinking about it. 

Every assignment involved a ton of writing, but it was never really that painful to get the assignments out. A lot of people had anxiety about how to score all of the points, but if you just read what they want you'll probably get most of the points.

The exam was kind of annoying, since it was worded confusingly, but we were allowed to use the course videos, transcripts, and Google/ChatGPT as well, so they were not too bad.

In the end, I assume most people taking this class are doing it for the interactive intelligence specialty, and don't really care about this review. But for what it's worth, the class was decently interesting, and not too hard even though it kept me busy. I'd recommend it for someone who wants to learn Python or for someone interested in cognition and how cognition concepts are applied with code.

This is not a Joyner class. This class was recorded when he was still a PhD student. KBAI lectures easily violate every single thing taught in HCI. 

Cons
- Boring, repetitive, pointless lectures.
- Poor assignments and projects.
- You can hardcode through the assignments and RPM and call it 'Learning by Recording Cases'

Pros
- It is easy to get an A with minimal effort.
- Coding: Using Pillow or OpenCV (for image manipulation). Implementing BFS/DFS/A* algorithms.

Take this course if you are looking for low-effort easy A.

Worst class I have taken in OMSA (10 taken). Very time demanding, but not at all rigorous. Curriculum is extremely high-level and you will learn nothing that can actually be put into practice. Math for non-majors vibes. Nonetheless you will be drowning in busy work with weekly deliverables that always have a written report component and often have a code-based component as well. 

TAs are also drowning having to grade this so they just quickly check off the rubric. If you do the same, you'll get 100 even if your quality of work is terrible. Tip: always overfit the visible autograder data as you will not be penalized. You can even hardcode it - just call it case-based reasoning.

There are homeworks, mini-projects, a major project with four milestone deliverables, exams, and a complicated engagement process all at once. None of these are well executed. Easy A it you do the assignments, but you will work hard and learn nothing. I advise strongly against taking this class.

I don't have a CS or engineering background and I found this class to be really easy and will finish with a high A. The programming assignments are nothing harder than a LC medium at best and the writing assignments, while a waste of time, provide free points so long as you follow the rubric. 

I would note that the role of TAs in this course is not great. Here, the TAs are there for operational support, not to clarify questions about lecture content. This is pretty annoying since the lectures are very dated with poor audio and incorrect/incoherent captions. However, outside of name dropping a few lecture concepts here and there for the writing assignments, they aren't really needed since the exams are open book.

The class average on the exams were around an 80%. I think this is heavily skewed to the left due to some really bad performers. Do note, that some of the exam questions were very poorly worded. This led to a lot of non-native English speakers to struggle.

The content is interesting from a historical perspective and to add flavor and depth to some of the challenges still currently facing modern connectionist AI (e.g. commonsense reasoning, planning, logic). It seems unlikely that these techniques will prove the key to AGI, but you never know, and having more tools in one's toolset is always a good thing.

This semester had a clusterfuck around peer review, Dr. Goel was largely absent from participation, and the TA staff was okay at best.

You also need to follow the rubrics to the letter to get a good grade. But once you do that, the rest is up to you. This class epitomizes the concept of you get out what you put in. 

You can sleep through the class and not apply a single concept from the lectures and brute force solve the mini-projects and use trivial heuristics to solve RPM and you can still get an A. Or you can spend some time digesting the lectures and reading the extra material to really feel the sense of where these topics can go. 

I enjoyed the material a lot, so the class was a net positive for me.

I can't recommend this class. This is my 9th class and it's one of the worst. I took HCI from Joyner and it was amazing, I thought this would be similar and it's complete polar opposite. 

I think you can see what this class use to be like and the elements are still there, but while the class has been updated, it hasn't culled away any of the content in 3+ years. It really is a constant barrage of assignments and things to do and its every single week. There is no break. Not even for Thanksgiving or for GT's fall break, and I know it's online but every Fall class I have taken before this gave some sort of breathing room. 
 
This is the standard week for this class: 2-3 hour lecture videos. 3 peer review (which is graded by a computer and they swear it's not based on word count but it is), office hours, a coding assignment (some really small but most are very involved 300+ lines)  and a 5-page paper explaining your code. And to top it off you have to participate in the discussion board to receive participation points. 

Additionally, you will get nickel and dimed on points for the rubric that the TA won't follow. I seriously had multiple custom deductions on assignments which at that point why even use a rubric. You can submit a regrade request but it's not as easy as just requesting it, you have to submit a doctoral thesis with a 3 page paper explaining why you got points taken off (and they swear that the TAs are not subjective, but again, they are)

The project is also terrible. In theory it sounds like a good idea, but the project literally comes down to more graphic analysis then it does AI. For the most part, everyone has the same idea of how to do things, but everyone's process is different. The exemplary examples they have are chosen based on what how well put together the paper looks but it's just for looks. Looking at some of the examples for help doesn't work because there are so many errors on them that you could find yourself coding in circles. 

TLDR: Skip this class unless you have a lot of free time on your hands and even then I would skip. Unless they cull away some of the fat and let the students breathe for a little bit this class is not worth it.

Grade: currently right on A/B border, might get a B.

Lectures: usually interesting, sometimes slow with the examples they walk through.  The lectures would really benefit from some good code examples.  Everything is presented very abstractly and translating what they present into actual usable code is a pretty huge challenge most of the time.

Mini projects: usually not too bad, I usually solved these with algorithms I didn't learn in the course, because they don't really present many algorithms, mostly just abstract framework.

Ravens Project: Very hard, I thought this was an interesting project to think through, but they don't give you any magical easy way to approach it in the lectures.  I learned a lot about opencv/image processing.  Get started early, I kept expecting the lectures to give me some a ha moment on how to approach these problems, but there is no easy solution (except farming gradescope which some students figured out how to do and shared it on the forum, pretty disappointed about this actually, they said they will fix this issue next semester).  To get an A you are probably going to end up with a brute force agent with miles of if statements, unless you think up something clever,  I ended up using a nearest neighbor approach which wasn't bad to code and worked well enough to get a 75/96.  

Tests: Awful, open everything, but trying to find jargon specific to the class which you can't find in the text book and it might just be stated briefly in a lecture video.  Best way to study I think is to just watch the lectures over and over and take good notes.

This class feels hard for the wrong reasons: 
-getting nitpicked on writing assignment points, 
-tests that don't really reflect actual problem solving skills, mostly just understanding jargon.
- ravens project is really hard and a fun challenge, but if some students figure out a gradescope farm you will be working your ass of while they get perfect scores for a hour or two of work (I didn't do this technique because it seemed like a complete waste of my time, not learning anything by doing this)
-10% participation grade which is no cake walk to get, need to reliably do peer reviews by Tuesdays and comment on the forum a lot.

Lectures: Interesting concepts in classical AI. Well-presented materials.

Assignments: The assignments are similar in format to Harvard's CS50 AI course, but more challenging (No starter code is provided, but you have the freedom to choose any methods you prefer). Overall, they were interesting and well-connected to the lectures (if you choose to use the methods introduced in the lectures).

Final project: 70% of my time was spent on the final project because I really enjoyed the project. Most people spent much less time and still did well.

Grading: Depends on your luck. Different TAs have different expectations. If you are assigned to a TA who interprets the rubric differently, you will get points deducted. This was what made this course stressful to a lot of people (You will find your heart beating at 150bpm whenever they release the grades).

Overall, this is a well-designed course for someone new to classical AI. The course was enjoyable but I would recommend against taking the class because you can just watch the lecture videos online and do the assignments yourself. This would save you from unnecessary stress. (I give it a rating of 1 not because the quality was bad, but because I think there is really no need to enroll in the class.)

This is an easy class if you have already taken AI. I even think you probably don't need to take it at all if you are in the ML track. If you're looking for a side class accompanying some big classes, or just looking to graduate, I would recommend it. Otherwise, I'd say you'll learn nothing.

Some tips:
1. For the RPM project, you have 3 milestones to work towards before submitting the final report. For each milestone performance score, even you could get 100% grade by solving half of the test problems, I still strongly encourage you to get them all if possible. That will save you a lot of effort on the final stage. 
2. Also for the RPM, make sure you come up with a way to effectively determine if two images are the same in the early milestones. Some images look the same, but in pixel-by-pixel they vary. This semester we have observed students using several ways, but none of them seem to work neatly. Most students are using a threshold.
3. For each writings, just refer to the rubric. The rubric is comprehensive and clear. And that's the best part of this class.

I agree with all the reviews posted so far from the Fall 2023 class. Although previous semesters had some positive and some negative reviews, I'm not surprised to see only negative reviews from this semester.

Pros:
Assignments are easy to understand. Assignments can be worked on ahead of time. This course was really flexible in terms of scheduling. Work load is dispersed quite evenly throughout the semester (some of the final assignments are easier but at that point you should be working on your final project)

Cons:
Grading can be quite subjective due to the nature of essays. The course videos appear related to the assignments, but they are related in superficial ways. Two snafus during the course lead to large disruptions in learning.

This class really needs the help of an involved professor. The lack of an involved professor made this course seem like a circus.

KBAI Review

TL;DR I am a Mech Eng and Software Eng and I learned absolutely nothing worth anything in this course. You basically spend the whole semester solving problems each week using whatever algorithm you want but call it an “Agent”. The material is outdated and I am shocked that this is allowed in the curriculum of a top 10 graduate CS program.

I’d recommend for - students who have no/little software background and want an easy start and can tolerate material that will likely be irrelavent if you want to do anything with AI as well as students who just want an easy A to get MS credentials. Or if you like structured learning environments and want to pay to practice solving problems that you could just do on your own.

I’d NOT recommend for - students who genuinely want to learn something relavent in the AI space and can’t tolerate wasting your time having to memorize and regurgitate outdated information so you can pass exams.

———DETAILED RATINGS----

Organization: Excellent
The organization and responsiveness of the TAs is excellent. At no point in the course was I stressed out because I awas unclear about something or left wondering for days/weeks. When tweaks were made, they were clearly communicated. (Unfortunately, however, you only have to get a B in a course to be a TA so many of them are not particularly knowledgeable. They are basically just glorified grading tools. Don’t ask them a sophisticated question about….idk equivalent problem representations…. or they will break and take points away for non-conformity lmao)

Grading: Fair
There was nothing unreasonable or unexpected grading-wise if you know how to read the rubric and check the boxes.

Workload: Way too much busy work
I probably work a bit slower than average and with the exception of the first assignment or two everything I did for this class felt like torturous busy work. I think to give us a break whey made the last few assignments easier and maybe some people appreciated that but I felt it was just more mindless work…I’d have preferred an actual dropped assignment or something so I can focus on research for a week and forget about class work.

(Note - I can’t say anything about the workload compared to other OMSCS courses as this is my first one)

Material: Outdated and irrelevant in the AI space
This was the main frustration for me in this course. I do not care (more than I have to for survival) about social credibilitly. I care about learning and my efforts and research helping the world. This classes wasted 4 months of my time (hyperbole acknowledged) solving weekly problems I don’t care about and watching 25 lectures that made me want to break my monitors. Whats hilarious is that if you used the methods we “learned” in class on the assignments, it would have made the assignments harder to do then just using simple heuristics and search algs. 

A much more appropriate name for this course would be "Ancient AI", "Applied Algorithms", "Narrow AI", “Techniques for Dumb Robots”, ...¯\_(ツ)_/¯

There are two intellectually distasteful things in this class for me 1) you have to learn the KBAI rebranding of existing concepts you already learn far more broadly and efficiently in other classes (ie. algorithms and data structures) and 2) the whole class is about various static algorithms that people have come up with in the past to solve AI problems that have produce terriblly narrow and non-extensible AI systems like those terrible phone robots that you have to get past to talk to real people about your problem. Sure, these systems work for some narrow applications but they are just static algorithms, not AI. Or like your Roomba….basically algorithms for dumb, narrow “AI".

There are enough actually challanging problems in the world that require understanding complex processes and so in a top tier program making students waste their time memorizing KBAI's rebranding of things they a) already know by another name or b) can learn in algorithms classes more efficiently is truly yuck. 

In short, this class is a waste of brain space because its basically a rebranding of things you should already know if you take, math and other fundamental CS courses. If you want cognition, take a neuroscience or another course. Not this. Otherwise just math, algorithms, and a minimal degree of introspection regarding how your own brain works is all you need to know everything in this class.

One additional TIP because I like a level playing field for those who still decide to take this class after my glowing review:
I (foolishly) completed my final project using IPR/DPR and a few little image processing techniques….but come to find out you can get 100% by just hardcoding all of the solutions and calling it "learning by recording cases” even though YOU are the one learning…not your socalled “agent". *facepalm*

———

Context:
Background: Mech Eng and Software Eng
Fall’23 - KBAI: A

This was a strange course. At first, I was excited for the challenge and learning something far different than anything else in OMSA. But I've had several issues with the course. It's a very "busy" course - frankly just too much. 

Many of the assignments seem to provide little learning value for me. Many of the mini-projects were a form of space-searches. The RPM project also seems promising, and I'd like to have focused more on it, but I just got a little bit burnt-out on the amount of coursework. I think people typically will say "deal with it, you're getting a GaTech degree, etc..." but in reality, less is more. People only have so much bandwidth, and additional assignments are diminishing (if not negative) returns. 

Outside of this, the course had a weird focus on catching cheaters. Much of the class was accused of cheating at one point on peer reviews (strangely). The teaching staff continued to double-down on this accusation, until they realized their errors, and retracted it. It was a very strange event overall. 

Not sure I would recommend this course without significant modifications.

Avoid this class if possible. So MUCH tedious and useless work. I honestly have learned little about AI. My writing probably has improved, after having to write a journal for every single coding assignment and every milestone of the semester long project. The midterm was like a reading comprehension exam with confusing words.

There is no AI in this course. All the randomly selected puzzles are to be solved by 'so-called' AI agents. There are many Mini-projects, Homework, and MileStones. For each assignment, you have to write ~4-5 pages of report (weekly), and that is too much for a course that is not AI. Each assignment is different and shallow in terms of learning. The course lectures are outdated and not useful nowadays. The grading is done by AI mostly, and I did not see a single comment on my submissions. The course will take a lot of time, and you will gain almost zero knowledge about AI. It is good for high-school kids, but not for MSc students in CS! I forgot to say that participation is mandatory and you have to write peer-review for others' assignments. This feedback takes so much time, and they are useless. I would call it 'abusing' student to assess submissions and grading based on their feedback reports (may save costs!). 10% for participation is insane, and there is no fun there.

I would only recommend taking this as your first course in OMSCS. Taking this in my last semester makes the tedious projects and boring lectures mind-numbing. There are non-stop peer review assignments, an unnecessary amount of papers and generally uninteresting content. I've worked way harder in classes like ML, RL or DL and had a blast. AI4R and Game AI are similar in workload and far more interesting.

I'm not a fan of the peer feedback thing - I came here to write this. I hope my grade isn't dependant on the other students.

I wish lectures were more relevant to the assignments.

I'm not learning anything that will be used outside of this course (and if I will, I've already learned it in undergrad) - and I work in reasearch, I think it's a more specific Data Structures/Algorithms course.

This class is busy work and basic problem solving that is beng used for publications. It's underwater basket weaving - but you don't have goggles and assignments are due every week.

This was my second semester and I picked HCI in the first sem. I received an A in this course over the Summer of 2023.

Lecture Videos:
The lecture videos were very abstract and left a room for a lot of thinking. I wish I could have the time during the summer to think about these abstract topics and apply these concepts in the Mini Projects and RPM Projects. But summer being very condensed it was not at all possible to do this. Most of my mini-projects were brute force approaches to solve the problem. 

If you really want to apply these concepts, I would recommend a spring / fall semester as it is not possible in the Summer. I had to work 1-2 weeks ahead to keep up with the pace of the course.

Assignments:
The course has 3 different types of assignment running parallel: The Mini Projects, the Homeworks and the RPM project.
All the assignments were easy with well layed out rubrics which helps to answer the questions. I lost marks mostly in Homework 2 and 3 as a lot of room to answer was left upon us Students, the lectures did not help much here.

Exams:
Exams were open book and easy. I have no complaints.

Overall:
I came in with little to no Python knowledge and was easily able to pick up the materials and RPM project on the go with lots of Google Searches, etc. This course is an easy course, I learnt a lot about Knowledge Based AI but I am not happy that I could not apply the concepts I wanted to for the RPM projects. I look forward to do this during my downtime.

I wish they could condense the course in the Summer so we can apply the concepts learnt and not rush through the semester. I would recommend picking this during Fall/Spring as unlike other courses, no assignments/homeworks have been dropped.

It is my 1st course in OMSCS. And I regret deeply for didn't take the time to check out reviews here and watch some videos of this useless course before paying for it. 
My opinions: 
1. videos are very useless, taking about concepts in a way like a daily conversation anyone can come up in school. In the end, teach students bascially nothing if not to take exams 1 & 2. 
2. too much writing, feel like a course for MBA student. too much writing for homework, min-project, RPM. too time consuming. 
3. Joyner's file format is a joke. Joyner is also a terribel teacher, trying to connect everything in the lecture to RPM, which makes zero sense. 
4. serious questions questioning lecture videos/notes don't get answers from teaching team. I suppose they trap themselves with poorly prepared notes and videos. 

Overall, just don't take this one unless you are required to do so.

Overall, I didn't learn as much as I wanted to in this course. It was alright, but not what I hoped for. Most projects could be brute forced, a lot of writing that seemed fairly pointless, Joyner Peer Feedback which was almost always useless forms of "good job" from fellow classmates. I will say I really appreciated everything being unlocked right away, I powered through lectures and assignments usually being 3-4 weeks ahead of schedule on work. Taking this class in the summer was pretty manageable. I got basically 100 on all mini projects and homeworks. 94/110 on Exam 1 and 92/110 on Exam 2 and 64/96 for the semester long final project with 50/50 on the final project writeup. This secured a solid A for me. If you know python, you are probably fine for the class, as you see even a meh score on the final project doesn't drag you down too much. Just stay up to date on the schedule (or work ahead). I wish there was slightly more challenging homework that really required application of AI rather than brute force algorithms that you pitch as AI in your reports. Literally with any approach you take, just follow the rubric and drop some keywords and you score full points. The Artificial Intelligence course in OMSCS is much harder but much more informative in terms of AI techniques and approaches. I expected more from this class, but oh well, it was an easy enough A for me.

I'm reviewing this class after receiving an "A" grade for the Summer 2023 term. Overall I had a positive experience with this course.

- This class could very easily be renamed "Applied Computer Vision" or "Applied Algorithms" considering the main RPM project, and mini-projects, respectively. The lectures do not go into any detail about OpenCV / Pillow / NumPy, so expect a very "hands-on" style deep-dive into these topics. The class also expects a decent familiarity with Python and about good programming principles in general.

- You probably shouldn't take this course during the summer. While it's possible to get an A, it will probably interfere with your life more than you want it to, and you will not have as much time to grasp the concepts in the lectures. Many of the assignments will feel rushed, and there are some weeks where both a homework / mini-project / exam is due the same week as as an RPM milestone; this is not ideal.

- Dr. Joyner, as usual, does an amazing job at administering the course, and allows students many opportunities for grade improvement. As is usual with his courses, expect the extra work of giving Peer Feedback every week. You will also find yourself looking on the EdStem forums a lot for this course, not only for the extra participation threads, but also for the assignments themselves (more on that later).

- The weakest point of this class is the lectures. Dr. Ashok Goel was the initial creator of the course, and Dr. Joyner is a co-host of the lectures. The lecture material does not really help while doing the assignments. Most of the material is very conceptual, and only a few of the lectures series have a real, technical description of an algorithm you should use on an assignment. I found this disappointing because the lectures became a chore every week. Instead of learning the material I would later apply in an assignment, it felt like I was learning the theory for the sake of learning the theory.

My recommendation to the course maintainers was for them to drop somewhere between 33 - 40% of the lecture videos, and with that remaining space, create new lecture videos which focus on implementation. The course covers so many topics that it does feel a bit overwhelming. Those videos in the 33 - 40% felt to me like topics which I only needed to know for the exams, and nothing else. It would be nice if the course could give some basic ideas / tutorials on computer vision fundamentals, and about how actually useful parts of the course material can be implemented in code.

This was a great course. the content is well organized and Dr. Joyner goes above and beyond on helping the students stay on track by sharing and posting on ed lessons the week announcements. 

The concepts of the class are not hard to understand but do require you to pay attention and think about them.
The interaction on the forum was really good and it really helps to figure out details on the projects. 

There is a primary project that you build during the semester and 5 mini projects. All the material is available on day 1 so you can work ahead but there are weekly discussions on the topics assigned for the current week. 

All of the projects can be built based on the material from the class, at least conceptually. in practice, you will need some knowledge of Python but nothing that you can't learn as you take the course. 

The main project involves image processing but is very light and you could even go ahead without it. PIL and OpenCV will be your friends.

Overall, this is a good course. The coding assignments are fun and they’re not too tough if you have any Python experience. The exams are open note and all multiple-selection T/F type questions, so it’s not too stressful. The material is pretty basic. So, if this is an early course in the program, you’ll get eased into some material. But if it’s later course, you might be a little bored.

Biggest downside is that there’s a LOT of writing. Way too much writing. Writing about your code. Shorter writing prompts based on course material. Write about other student’s assignments. Just way too much writing. If you can’t pump out 5-8 pages of writing easily, you’re going to have a bad time.

This class was not very difficult.  What I liked is that Dr. Joyner opened up all the assignments (even the midterm/final exam) at the beginning of the semester.  This allows students to get a head start on assignments.  I highly recommend to get a good 1 assignment ahead so you don't need to get stressed out.

There is a new assignment to do every week, so as long as you've got reasonable time management skills, you'll do fine.

In addition, get ALL the participation points you can, it can easily drag down your grade if you slack off on doing it.
David Joiner & Ashok Goel are great instructors for the class! The workload isn't too bad and there's no group projects (thank god, lol)

This is an amazing introductory course in the program that I *wish* I had taken as my first OMSCS course. Lectures are engaging and easy to understand. I paired this class with AIES and was easily able to get an A. Good mix of programming and writing.

I went into this course with zero "AI" experience and was surprised at how digestable and easily understandable everything was. The hardest portion of this class is the semester long project but I thought it was a really fun assignment.

I understand that writing the papers can be annoying, but they are actually really simple to write and easy As (as long as you follow the syllabus). 

Dr. Joyner is so good at crafting these courses that are challenging and engaging while also fostering a sense of community through Ed Discussion. He actually cares whether you learn something from a course which I can't say about other courses I've taken in OMSCS (AIES, Global Entrepreneurship).

Don't be intimidated by the title! If I can do it, I promise you can

Pros:

- The programming assignments are somewhat challenging but extremely doable. The lectures give you everything you need to solve the projects. If you're stuck you can also check Ed Discussion where someone will definitely have posted a high-level description of the solution (this helped me so much!)

- Lectures are really engaging (as long as you haven't fallen behind and are binging them)

- Helpful student engagement and discussion in Ed Discussion

Cons:

- While I really enjoyed the semster long project, it kind of felt like there was the "one way" to do it with IPR/DPR. I know that's not true, but it really felt that way. I wish the lectures and the RPM problems were closer to each other.

Background: BS degree in civil engineering with ~2 years of development experience. KBAI was my second course in the program after HCI.

As mentioned in this course, there are basically four schools of AI: designing agents that (1) think optimally, (2) act optimally, (3) think like humans, or (4) act like humans. Knowledge-Based Artificial Intelligence is focused on (3) - how can we design AI agents that think like humans? With that in mind, this course has significant overlap with cognitive science and philosophy in an effort to understand how humans think. The lectures fly at a pretty high level, but I found them interesting and thought-provoking. Many folks mention the writing assignments as a drawback to this course, but it's to be expected in a Joyner course and I think it's perfectly reasonable for graduate-level coursework. A lot of the writing is focused on communicating your problem solving approach for homework assignments, which I consider to be an essential skill. It doesn't really matter how slick your algorithms are if you can't explain to anyone how they work.

Overall, I would recommend taking KBAI. I didn't have any prior experience with AI, so this was a nice introduction to the field. You'll definitely improve your Python skills, and you'll get your feet wet with rudimentary NLP and computer vision. I really enjoyed the semester-long RPM project because I got to learn more about NumPy and OpenCV.

With that said, I will agree with a prior comment about how KBAI feels like the "underwater basket weaving" of AI. Throughout the semester I couldn't quite get past the fact that it all felt too high level and simplistic. It was a very unique time to take this course because it happened smack in the middle of the ChatGPT explosion, and so I couldn't escape the feeling that the little logic problems presented in the assignments fall short of what "real AI" looks like. If you're looking to dive deep into algorithms, AI or ML might be a better choice.

I thoroughly enjoyed how KBAI combines writing and programming to create a well-informed understanding of AI at a high level. The course is structured around three major assignment types: Mini-Projects that leverage a particular AI strategy to solve programming problems in Python; written assignments that require analysis of AI topics and their application to real-world scenarios; and a semester-long project on using Python to engage in image transformation detection for solving Raven's Progressive Matrices. These assignments rotated weekly, which I felt was helpful in ensuring that I didn't get burnt out on a particular topic.

I found myself extremely overwhelmed by KBAI at the start of the course but eventually found a groove that made the workload manageable. The first Mini-Project was significantly more difficult for me to complete than any other assignment - I ended up with a 50-something on GradeScope and seriously contemplated withdrawing from the course only 2 or 3 weeks in. That said, once I better understood the requirements for each of the Mini-Projects and major project milestones, the work became almost trivial. Prior knowledge of Python is a major plus that will help you significantly throughout this course. 

Many reviewers of this course have branded its lecture videos as a distraction from the actual course content, and generally I tend to agree. The lectures cover various problem-solving and knowledge topics at a high level but never provide details on how they could be implemented in a programming environment; I found some lectures to be more useful than others in terms of guiding me toward solutions. Knowledge of the lecture video content is only truly necessary for the written Homework assignments and the 2 exams.

The real secret to success in this course lies in community participation: go-getter students are very eager to share how they completed particular assignments or problems, allowing you to skip over the process of deliberating how to solve such problems and instead focus on implementation. I highly recommend lurking around Ed if you are stuck on something.

This course rewards those who are either: a) willing to dedicate significant hours to coming up with original solutions; or b) clever at making most of the resources offered to them and not obsessing over a perfect score. You can easily maintain a high grade by being deliberate about which assignments you're capable of getting a 100 on and letting these pad some of your lower-performing code submissions. I finished with a mid-90s final grade despite earning a 76/100 on my final project's performance.

Background: 
This is my first course in the OMSCS program. I have a BS in Computer Engineering and most of my programming experience is in C#/.NET. Took a 5-6 year break from school and currently work as a Software Developer professionally.

Overall:
This course is a great introductory course for those who took a long break from undergrad or for those who want to get better at programming without taking a deep dive into highly complex topics. All the mini-projects and main project require you to use Python. From my personal experience, I took most of the time (for the first month) trying to understand how to set up Python and getting used to the differences in syntax compared to C#. Also, an initial lack of knowledge in NumPy, PIL, and OpenCV libraries, which are essential for the Final project, significantly increased development time for the Project Milestones. Although the Homeworks are basically long essays, I found them to be the least time consuming assignments of the course. I struggled in this course initially because a lot of the mini-projects required knowledge in different data structures, which I lacked, and had to play catch up to eventually get an A in the course. Mini-Project 2 and 3 were the most difficult assignments, based on my experience, so do not get discouraged if you score low on those. 

Tips:
• Use the course forum if you feel like you are struggling in the programming assignments. (The other students in the course are very helpful and give great advice)
• Try to write additional peer feedbacks if you don't plan to be active in the forum. (I found I had to play catch up towards the end of the semester for my participation points)
• Play around with the Python libraries that are used for the RPM project when you have free time. (It will help lower development time for your project)
• Focus on the rubric for the assignments rather than longevity.

What I got out of the course:
• I improved on my Python programming
• Learned different ways to approach problems
• Better understanding of the importance of planning
• Better awareness of time requirements for a Graduate course

I would definitely recommend this course as an introductory course for the OMSCS program based on the overall good experience I had.

I really enjoyed this class, I love a Joyner class in general. Lecture material is interesting and the projects are all just the right amount of hard. You have to think and put in effort but none took more than maybe 5 hours for the week. There is a paper due with every project, but they take no time to write up and do not have to be anything crazy to get full points. Feel like I learned a lot and wasn't stressed over this class. I really looked forward to working on the course project (there are weeks set aside just to work on the overall project).

My first course in the OMSCS program, my background is BS in mechanical engineering and I have been a working professional for 8 years. My CS background is limited, and my work does not use python. 
With that being said, a great first course! I enjoyed the jumpstart into programming in python, and the class has a great discussion forum that is very lively. I had to get used to the flow, you typically have to write ~4 pages a week on homework, and have to work on creating a working code that is submitted to be graded.
The beginning of the course did require a lot of work, the first coding project took me 15 hours to complete but only because my programming was rusty and needed to get up to speed. After that initial kick I got the hang of it, and really enjoyed how goofy some of the project was. I will say after each exam I felt like I didn't learn much about KBAI as some of the definitions were hard to pick up from the lessons. This course to me was more about the enjoyment I got from the homework, mini-projects, and final. 
Highly recommend to anyone who is in a similar boat and wants to dive in. Be warned, I did say 13 hours a week, but in the beginning I did have some 20-25 hour weeks, but towards the end I had some 4-5 hour weeks to balance it out. And yes I am a nerd and kept track of all my time, the actual average was 12.3 hours, but decided to round up to be on the safe side if someone is trying to plan out a semester workload.

I love this class! It's my first class and a great transition to the program. The projects are so much fun and really improve my coding skills. Students on the forum are always there to share ideas and tips and help each other. It's surprising how friendly the classroom environment is despite being online. The TAs who post on the forum are nice and professional, even when people post angry complaints. 

The biggest complaint I've seen is the writing. There's writing every week. Personally, I don't think it's that bad since the required JDF format has big margins. Just make sure you hit the rubric and be clear with your thoughts.

Although the lectures focus more on the theories, which seems to be a masters-level thing, you can tell the professors put in a lot of thoughts to  incorporate the materials in the assignments. 

The RPM project is my favorite part of the class. It's so rewarding to see it come together by the end of the semester. The discussions on the forum on various approaches and testing make it feel like you are working as a team.

Everything's available at the start of the semester which is really nice for working ahead. Lastly, this class is very organized as it's one of Dr. Joyner's class. It just makes your life so much easier when everything's clear.

I just finished the final exam.  It is open book/note/lecture/everything, but I realized how little I learned in this class.

Pros:
Everything is released right away.  All assignments are online, so you can get started whenever you want (barring those assignments changing for the next semester).

Professor is active in the forums but that should be the norm, not a pro.

Lots of graded assignments to cushion the blow if you do poorly on something.

Cons:
Lectures are just high level and hand wavy.  Examples that are abstract to the point of being absurd.  "Suppose a robot wants to buy a cup of coffee".  That stuff is just laughable. This content has nothing to do with the mini-projects or RPM.  MPs can almost be solved with a search algorithm (BFS), other MPs you can just hack something together.

You can get 70% performance on RPM with affine model, DPR/IPR hacks and a look up table.  No reason to go beyond that since you'll lose only a couple points on your final grade.

80% is the average success rate for students on RPM performance, rarely anyone gets 100%.  So your grade is penalized by virtue of tackling the problem.  80% performance should be 100% of that part of the grade.

Some of the homework questions were tangential and not with-in the scope of the class.  But it is easy busy work to pad your grade, so maybe a pro.

Cognitive Science is just pseudo-philosophy.  Unfortunately, this class is just that with a sprinkling of AI and not the other way around.  KBAI feels like the underwater basket weaving of AI.  Maybe interesting to think about (if that is your thing) but completely useless in the real world.

My $0.02:

This class failed since it didn't teach me anything.  That is what I learned on the final exam.  Just topics that you watch a video for, take some notes and you'll probably forget a week or two after the semester is done.  I wish this class showed some actual application to the real world.  How does KBAI tie into Chat GPT? Does Boston Dynamics implement KBAI into their robots?  Those kinds of things.

I recommend checking out the course page and see if this is something of interest before you register.  It is an easy class to get a B and fulfill the Interactive Intelligence specialization requirement, but kind of a waste of time when you could be learning something useful or that would apply to your future career.  I feel like I left AI having learned new skills but I leave KBAI wondering if I should have just taken ML instead.

Pros: -The videos of this class are absolutely the best. They're short and sweet but you'll also learn a lot from them, I felt they're changing the way I think.
-Exams are reasonable, not too hard, not too difficult for someone watched all the lectures.
Cons: Pretty much everything else :) 
-Every single week you have to write a journal, but the issue isn't in writing them as much as how they get graded. During the whole semester, so many students complained on ED that they didn't get graded fairly which is kind of true, your grade depends on how nice the TA is and they're all subjective so it's hard to argue against it. For some reason the professor didn't get engage in any of those threads.
-TAs are there to review those journals, they're rarely engaged in anything would truly help the students.
-The projects are silly and you don't need AI to solve them, they're all solvable through brute force, in fact, I haven't seen anyone else in the class solving them in a different way based on the journals which I had to review during the peer review process.

Long story short, take that class if you don't have other options, otherwise, watch the videos of the class on your own, they're available online for everyone.

I have to rant about KBAI to someone or I will lose my mind

I had to write a paper about what a sandwich is. How to play UNO using if-then statements. What free will is. What a joke is.

This class is a joke. Every homework is just busy work. Here's a great line from the prompt for home work 3:

As we all know, our appreciation for literature is only increased when we painstakingly tear it apart and analyze it like a chemical compound, so let’s do that here—and save pondering how to design an AI agent that can understand the sarcasm of that sentence for another day.

No! Professor, are you serious? No! I am in a Comp Sci program. I am a professional with a life. This isn't funny. This is you looking your student in the face and saying "im making you do unrelated busy work instead of what you came here for, and I'm going to laugh at you about it." This is every homework.

I hate this class. It makes the whole OMSCS program feel like a bad joke of an online school. I literally lost points today because a TA didn't like how I defined what a hotdog is. Are you kidding me? In a masters level grad program about computer science?

The first thing I ever programmed on my own was an if-then stupid little program to play blackjack. Turns out that was actually masters level work because Joyner was happy to assign an UNO if-then stupid little program as homework (and then call it an "AI agent" lol). This class is a literal insult to the intelligence of its students.

But at least we get cool AI based homeworks right?

NO. NO, YOU REALLY DONT.

For every assignment you can just brute force your way to perfect score, and what's more, that's usually the best way to do it. The lectures are full of stuff about AI that only gets applied when students drop buzzwords from lectures to try to satisfy TAs who want to see us "apply what we learned". In other words, replacing the word "class" with "frame" and "variable" with "slot". Boom, you can do AI now.

The TAs for this class have no business deciding if I defined free will sufficiently at a masters level. I have no business trying to do so at a masters level. I'm not here for philosophy, I super don't care what Joyner or his TAs feel about free will. Like, at all. And if they care what I think then they're even more bonkers than I thought. What even is this class?

I don't know. I'm never taking another Joyner class again.

This was my first course in the program. I feel comfortable writing this review six weeks before the end of the semester as I have fully explored all the course content, submitted all my code, and submitted almost all of written work. I currently have a 98 in the course and fully expect to maintain an ‘A’. This is a relatively easy course if you have a background in CS, but make no mistake, it is time-consuming. I was only able to work ahead because I have significantly more time than the average student to put toward schoolwork.

PROS:
--	The content of the course is interesting. It feels like a cross between an intro to AI and an intro to cognitive science. I learned a lot from the different concepts covered in the lectures, from semantic networks, to incremental concept learning, to analogical reasoning. If you’re interested in the nature of intelligence and minds/possible minds, you’ll probably find this stuff fascinating.
--	The lectures are well produced and easy to consume. I think this is the case with most courses in the program, but like I said, this is my first course, so I really appreciated it.
--	Because the course is popular and has such a high student capacity, Ed was always very active. Every question asked was answered quickly and satisfactorily by a fellow student or a TA. Communicating with others on Ed was actually one of my favorite parts of the course. I learned a lot just from these interactions.
-- David Joyner. I just love the guy.
-- The programming was pretty fun. If you’re looking for something on the easier side, are just getting started in the program, or don’t have much background in CS, the projects are a good way to get some exercise with python and maybe a little numpy.
--	The exams are fair and very well put together. No gotchas, no ambiguity (that I saw), and the difficult level was appropriate for an open-note, open-internet format–challenging but not too hard. That said, I think I would have preferred a somewhat easier, closed-note exam format. I personally learn more that way. 

CONS:
--	I’m not sure how directly useful the course content is in industry. This isn’t a euphemism; I’m honestly not sure. Judging from what others have said (I’m not in tech professionally yet), these concepts probably fall on the lower end of practicality. However, I still think they’re useful at a high level when considering what the properties of a truly intelligent agent are.
--	The programming assignments, including the central Raven’s Progressive Matrices project, don’t require you to use the course material and thus end up not complementing the course the way they should. To me, this is the biggest flaw of the class. Your program results are auto-graded, so as long as your output gets you across the finish line, whatever got you there doesn’t matter. Most people in my experience wised up quickly to easy visual heuristics (DPR/IPR and others) they could get away with to solve RPM problems. For the mini-projects, there were a handful of people who worked ahead very quickly, figured out short cuts to solving them all, and then described the easiest solutions on Ed. Others will rightly point out that when it comes to learning you get out what you put in, but when you’re assigned 4-8 pages to write every single week, it’s hard to not take the easy path when it’s sitting right there in front of you. Speaking of which…
--	There’s just too much writing. Some of the writing is fun (I had a blast writing about consciousness for homework 3), but the RPM journals get tedious. There are four milestone journals PLUS the big writeup for the final project. This is in addition to writeups for each of the five mini-projects, the three (long) homeworks, AND the peer feedback you have two write each week. I much rather would have spent more time coding.

Overall, I’m right on the fence with recommending or not recommending this course. Would I take it again? In its current form, I don’t think so. It’s just way too easy to not learn very much, and I wish there were more mechanisms in place to hold students’ feet to the fire. However, if you’ve got time to put the work in and feel you won’t succumb to the temptation of taking the easy route on assignments, I can imagine this being a rewarding experience.
Very well taught class. It was my first in the OMSCS and I recommend it.

KBAI was one of the best courses I've ever taken, and I highly recommend it for anyone who REALLY wants to learn how to think differently about complex problems (both in AI but also in a general technical atmosphere). Let me list the pros and cons below.

Pros:
• You learn a LOT. From the moment you enter the class to the day you leave, you are constantly learning about the parallels in how humans think and how we can mimic AI machines to think like us! Very fascinating stuff.
• The course project is for sure a shiny badge for your resume. The semester-long Raven's Progressive Matrices Agent that you build will definitely teach you a lot about the course subjects, but it'll also look really good on your professional profiles or resume! Even if your Agent isn't in the top percentile, the learning you do and all the code you write for it over the semester is for sure an achievement regardless. 
• The Mini-Projects allow you to improve your coding. I knew programming decently well coming into this class, but after completing the coding projects needed, my python programming skills have improved drastically! 
• The sense of community on Ed is like nothing else. Seriously, the Ed forum was a lifesaver for this class. The professor and TA pretty much always foster a community of learning and making mistakes and helping eachother out. I can't recall a single time where they took down a post where students were helping eachother think about problem solving techniques and offering advice. You could tell that most of the teaching staff wanted students to succeed and help one another.
• In my personal opinion, I think it's extremely important to have good written communication skills as a developer, and with all the reports you write in this course it definitely gives you the opportunity to work on and hone those skills. Writing reports for every single project can seem annoying at times, but I assure you'll come out a better writer! 
• You can tell the Professor loves this course and is dedicated to student success. Dr. Joyner is amazing at what he does, and it's clear throughout every point in this class. From the weekly assignment reminders, to the fun engaging lectures, and the occasional responses on Ed posts, I liked knowing I was in a class where I felt appreciated and valued as a student. 
• You WILL get out from this course what you put IN. If you make a decent effort to learn the concepts, complete the course project, and all the other assignments, you will come out of this class feeling like a different person. You will be equipped with a huge toolbelt of knowledge to go and tackle problems you never thought you could before. I came in knowing nothing about computer vision, and now I'm able to do technical analysis on images and process pixel counts and use those to make assumptions about what an image is showing me... very cool stuff!
• You have the ability to work ahead! The thing I loved the most about this course was having the entire class given to you day one. You have a syllabus and deadlines for assignments, but you as a Student are able to pick how far ahead you want to work. This saved me so many times while working fulltime, because there were weeks where work or sickness caught hold of me but I had worked 2-3 weeks ahead and so I was seldom worried about my assignments. If you can, I HIGHLY implore you to get ahead wherever you can in this class. Some students worked so far ahead they got the entire month of December off and to themselves. So keep that in mind when taking this class.

Cons:
• Lecture Exercises are somewhat outdated (it can get kind of annoying because by the end of the semester I wasn't even actively doing them as I knew most of the results would be wrong anyways). Just focus on the lectures themselves.
• Not necessarily a con, but rather a warning. You REALLY need to be a competent programmer. I don't recommend this class for anyone just learning how to code. A lot of the projects in this class require intensive programming.
• Grading isn't very standardized. I only encountered this issue towards the very end of the course, but despite my reports being extremely similar in structure and format from week-to-week, some TA's may take that as a 100, and other TA's may take that as a 75. 
• Exams are fair, but my only hesitance with them is the way the questions are worded. I don't know how non-native english speakers even take them, as being one myself made it extremely difficult to understand the question wording a lot of the time. Hopefully they improve that in the future but for now, question wording can get really convoluted and you'll spend 2-3 minutes just deciphering what the question is asking. (Exam times are also on the shorter side so beware of that).
• Peer Reviews did not help. In this class you're required to submit peer reviews for others' reports as part of participation. For one, most of the peer reviews I got didn't help me at all, but also in my cohort it actually caused issues in regards to retaliation. Students who took critical feedback would then go and "reputation strike" other students, which I think at the end caused a lot of issues that could be avoided outright if reviews are abolished or at least give reviewers option to remain anonymous.

My first course in the program. It's an excellent "re-entry" into school (20 years past since undergraduate).  I loved the concepts of thinking about problem solving and the direct links between human cognition and the algorithms implemented by computer "AI agents".  It really expanded how I think about computer program design and the parallels to human thinking/problem solving.  The programming itself wasn't too difficult.  I improved my python skills immensely - but YMMV. My biggest complaint was the writing components - the weekly papers covering your program did become a bit of a chore.  The class message forum was lively, helpful and educational.

I review each aspect of this class in detail here, in this 5 min video
https://youtu.be/mCsmaXxZL60
Cheers!

Before I begin my review, I should let you know that I am not in the OMSCS program. I am in the C-track (Computational Data Analytics) for the OMSA program and took this course because C-track students have to take 2 CS courses for the program. This course got one of the better reviews of the ten CS course options listed for the C-track electives, so I decided to take this course. I'm disclosing this to let you know that I do not come from a pure CS background like most people that take this class, just to give you a heads-up.

Now for the review. To put it simply, this class just has way too much going on. I knew going into this class that there would be a decent amount of writing because a lot of the reviews on here mentioned it. But what most of those reviews don't mention is EXACTLY how much writing there is, which is what I am going to tell you right now so that you know. Don't say I didn't warn you.

Excluding the 2 exams, there are 13 assignments in total for this course, with all of them requiring a write-up. Here are the page total requirements for the assignments:

- 5 papers for a semester-long coding project: 5 pages per paper for the first 4, and then up to 10 pages for the 5th one.
- 5 papers for 5 different coding mini-projects: Up to 4 pages per paper
- 3 papers for 3 different theory-based homework assignments based on lecture material: Up to 6 pages per paper (4 pages recommended)

In total, I did roughly 65 pages of paper writing for this course. I should note that not every page was all text. You are asked on some papers to include figures/diagrams, which can take up at least half of a page a lot of the time. But there was definitely more text than figures in my papers.

A paper is due every week, first thing Monday morning. And THEN you have to give peer feedback to 3 different students' papers that are randomly assigned to you for each of the 13 assignments. And the peer feedbacks that you submit are graded. If a student's paper meets all of the rubric's expectations and is really good, you can't simply write "This was a great submission and it met all of the expectations. Great job!" You will get a bad grade for that. You have to go into great detail and write in paragraphs why that student's submission was really good in order to get a good grade on your feedback, which I thought was redundant busy-work.

All of this writing makes it incredibly easy to fall behind on the lecture videos, which are fairly interesting but they're only helpful for the exams in my opinion. I thought there was a pretty big disconnect between the lecture material and the coding assignments for this course. They were incredibly high-level "whiteboard" explanations that didn't really give any good algorithm breakdowns or coding whatsoever. I literally didn't use any of the concepts covered in the course for the semester-long project because the project was too big and complex for any of these concepts to be applicable. And this seemed to be the class consensus based on discussions in the class forum. I would encourage you to pay attention to the discussions in the class forum because students share methods that they implemented in their mini-projects and semester-long project that really helped them out, and I found that to be pretty useful.

There's also no starter code for any of the coding assignments in this class - I didn't find this to be a big deal seeing as it is a grad-level CS course, but I figured I would just let you know this ahead of time as well.

The one good thing about this class is that because there are so many assignments in the course, everything is weighted pretty evenly and lightly. So doing really poorly on one assignment is not gonna affect your grade that much. I got roughly 60% on the semester-long project for this course and I'm either going to barely get an A or easily get a B in the course.

In terms of coding, I would say it is on the easier side for OMSCS students (it's all in Python, by the way). But my final advice to you regarding this course is this: if you are not required to take this course for your program, you need to SERIOUSLY consider whether you are willing to do a ton of excessive writing - between assignment write-ups, peer feedback, and coding - for a 4-month period. Because that's what you're gonna spend the vast majority of time doing in this course.

Knowledge-Based AI was my second/third course only after AI. I would like to say what I really loved about KBAI. The course material was easy to understand and digest. The projects were pretty great and while we had to think about them, they weren't that difficult to solve or submit. The TAs were really generous and helped out a lot. For an online student, the best tool that we used was Ed Discussions and Peer Feedback, as these were a semblance of actually interacting with the class. The students were extremely helpful and may be due to participation points, were really supportive throughout. 

There was not much I didn't like, but I would definitely say that this was a time-consuming class. Weekly Projects, Reports, and Submissions without any breaks were extremely exhausting. Even if I missed one week, I would lose a grade. Not saying that a Masters's Course should be any less rigorous but this is something the student should expect from this class. 

The only reason for bumping difficulty from 3 to 4 is to keep it aligned with the strict time-bound activities we need to perform. Overall I had the most fun in this class and would recommend students to take this class.

I'm taking this as a first OMSCS course, with 2 STEM degrees, some undergraduate CS coursework, and a functional (but rusty) grasp of python.

Noting that folks of widely ranging backgrounds take this course, I'd like to address some common criticisms.

1. There is too much writing. 
There is an assignment due basically every Sunday midnight (except exam weeks). Nearly every assignment is 50% Gradescope performance and 50% write up. If you bomb an assignment, it's not the end of the world.
